column1: A heart attack may occur when: - A tear in the plaque occurs.
This triggers blood platelets and other substances to form a blood a clot at the site that blocks most or all of the oxygen-carrying blood from flowing to a part of the heart muscle.

Heart attack may occur: - When you are resting or asleep - After a sudden increase in physical activity - When you are active outside in cold weather - After sudden, severe emotional or physical stress, including an illness Many risk factors may lead to the development of plaque buildup and a heart attack.
Chest pain is the most common symptom of a heart attack.
Rest and a medicine to relax the blood vessels (called nitroglycerin) may not completely relieve the pain of a heart attack.
A "silent heart attack" is a heart attack with no symptoms.
A health care provider will perform a physical exam and listen to your chest using a stethoscope.
- You may get nitroglycerin and morphine to help reduce chest pain.
- Angioplasty is often the first choice of treatment.

While under the care of your health care team, you will learn: - How to take medicines to treat your heart problem and prevent more heart attacks - How to eat a heart-healthy diet - How to be active and exercise safely - What to do when you have chest pain - How to stop smoking Strong emotions are common after a heart attack.
Most people who have had a heart attack take part in a cardiac rehabilitation program.

How well you do after a heart attack depends on several factors such as: - The amount of damage to your heart muscle and heart valves - Where that damage is located - Your medical care after the heart attack If your heart can no longer pump blood out to your body as well as it used to, you may develop heart failure.
